sub_subject.name: Speech, Rhetoric & Logic (The Trivium's Apex)
sub_subject.description: 13-year academic progression (K-12) for Speech, Rhetoric & Logic (The Trivium's Apex) (Language Arts & Humanities)

objectives.objective_text: Identify rhyming words.
Name words that start with the same sound (Alliteration).
Identify a simile (Using 'like' or 'as').
Name when something is exaggerated.
Identify Irony (saying the opposite of what you mean).
Identify patterns (A, B, A, B...).
Identify a logical conclusion.
Identify when an answer doesn't fit the question.
Name 'name-calling' as a bad way to argue.
Identify a Straw Man (pretending the other side is silly).
Identify the rhythm while reading.
Identify that butterflies in the stomach are normal.
Vote on a simple class choice.
Follow a simple time limit for speaking.
Remember the story without the book (Memory).
Listen to someone else's opinion without interrupting.
Listen to an opposing view and restate it.
Recall repeated words in a song.
Observe patterns in sentences.
Recall that we don't always mean exactly what we say (e.g., 'I'm freezing').
Observe personification (animals talking).
Recall that if all dogs bark, and Fido is a dog, Fido barks.
Observe that some things must be true if other things are true.
Recall that just because a friend does it, doesn't mean it's right.
Observe that two wrongs don't make a right.
Listen quietly while others read the Bible.
Listen to the answer before talking again.
Take turns speaking in a circle.
Raise hand to speak.
Follow the rules of a class discussion.
Participate in a structured 'Pro vs. Con' list making.
Understand the roles of 'Affirmative' and 'Negative'.
Explain the role of the judge/adjudicator.
Defend a position you personally disagree with (intellectual exercise).
Say the book, chapter, and verse numbers.
Tell a story with a beginning, middle, and end.
Structure a speech with an Introduction, Body, and Conclusion.
Put story pictures in order (Arrangement).
Choose fun words (Style).
Speak with a clear voice (Delivery).
Use strong verbs and adjectives (Style).
Use note cards sparingly (Memory).
Use hand gestures effectively (Delivery).
Explain methods of Loci or Mnemonics for Memory.
Defend the importance of Memoria for extemporaneous speaking.
Think of ideas before speaking.
Brainstorm a list of words.
Ask 'What do I want to say?'
Choose the best idea.
Use the '5 Ws' (Who, What, Where, When, Why) to find ideas.
Explain the purpose of the speech (inform, persuade, entertain).
Brainstorm topics using a mind map.
Select the best evidence for a point.
Explain the concept of 'Stasis' (the point of disagreement).
Defend the necessity of deep research for invention.
State an opinion using 'I think...'.
Give one reason for the opinion using 'because'.
Disagree politely ('I think differently').
Distinguish between a Fact and an Opinion.
Give three reasons to support a claim.
Respond to a counter-point with 'Yes, but...'.
Explain the difference between constructive and rebuttal speeches.
Defend a position using the Toulmin Model (Claim, Data, Warrant).
Summarize what a pattern in words is.
Explain Parallelism (e.g., 'I came, I saw, I conquered').
Use Anaphora (repeating the start of a sentence).
Explain Polysyndeton (many 'ands') vs. Asyndeton (no 'ands').
Defend the use of schemes to aid memory and impact.
Summarize the difference between literal and figurative.
Explain a Metaphor.
Explain the concept of Litotes (negating the contrary).
Defend the use of figurative language in Scripture.
Sort things into groups (Red things vs. Blue things).
Summarize an 'If... Then...' statement.
Explain what a premise is (a starting fact).
Explain Deductive vs. Inductive reasoning.
Defend the laws of logic (Identity, Non-Contradiction, Excluded Middle).
Summarize the Ad Hominem fallacy (attacking the person).
Explain the Bandwagon fallacy (everyone is doing it).
Explain the Slippery Slope argument.
Defend truth without resorting to fallacious reasoning.
Read a Bible verse clearly.
Hold the Bible respectfully while reading.
Read a narrative passage (e.g., David and Goliath) with expression.
Project voice so the back of the room can hear.
Pronounce biblical names correctly.
Explain the concept of 'Lector'.
Defend the public reading of Scripture as a central act of worship (1 Tim 4:13).
Recite a nursery rhyme from memory.
Use a happy or sad voice to match the poem.
Say rhyming words clearly.
Stand still while reciting.
Read a poem paying attention to punctuation (not just line breaks).
Use volume changes to make the poem interesting.
Memorize a classic poem (e.g., Stevenson or Rossetti).
Explain the difference between 'acting' and 'interpreting'.
Defend interpretation choices based on the text.
Stick to one main idea when talking.
Start with a 'Hello' and end with 'Thank you'.
Use pictures to help remember what to say.
Use 'signpost' words (First, Next, Finally).
Summarize the main points at the end.
Explain the importance of transitions between arguments.
Defend the necessity of a clear 'call to action'.
Stand up straight and look at the audience.
Speak loudly enough to be heard by everyone.
Share a 'Show and Tell' item with confidence.
Use deep breathing to calm nerves before speaking.
Practice a speech in front of a mirror or family.
Maintain eye contact with different parts of the room.
Turn nervous energy into enthusiasm.
Explain the concept of 'posture' and 'presence'.
Defend the message even when feeling fear.
Hold an object so everyone can see it.
Draw a picture to show the class.
Point to parts of a picture while talking.
Use a prop to tell a story.
Use a digital slide to show a photo.
Explain a diagram or map to an audience.
Avoid reading directly off the poster.
Explain how to cite sources on a slide.
Defend the choice of analog vs. digital aids for specific contexts.
Ask 'Why?' to understand better.
Take turns in a circle discussion.
Ask politely for information.
Ask open-ended questions (not just Yes/No).
Explain what someone else said to check understanding.
Ask 'What do you mean by that?'
Explain the value of admitting 'I don't know'.
Defend the pursuit of Truth over the pursuit of winning.
Analyze the structure of a Team Policy debate.
Interpret the resolution (the topic being debated).
Connect cross-examination questions to setting up an argument.
Interpret the 'Exordium' (Introduction) and 'Peroration' (Conclusion).
Organize points logically (Arrangement).
Analyze the 5 Canons as a system.
Interpret the use of rhetorical devices in Style (metaphor, alliteration).
Connect the structure (Arrangement) to the argument's strength.
Analyze the 'Common Topics' (Definition, Comparison, Relationship, Circumstance).
Interpret the audience's needs and values.
Connect the topic to a universal theme.
Analyze the 'Burden of Proof' (who has to prove it?).
Interpret the opponent's argument to find weaknesses.
Connect evidence (stats, quotes) to the claim.
Compare a normal sentence with a poetic one.
Analyze the effect of Antithesis (contrasting ideas).
Interpret the use of Chiasmus (A-B-B-A structure).
Connect the scheme to the emphasis of the point.
Compare Hyperbole (exaggeration) with Understatement.
Analyze Synecdoche (part for whole) and Metonymy (associated word).
Interpret the use of Rhetorical Questions.
Connect tropes to the imagination of the listener.
Compare General rules to Specific examples.
Analyze the structure of a Categorical Syllogism (All A are B...).
Interpret the difference between Valid (structure) and Sound (truth).
Connect logic to the nature of God (Logos).
Compare a good reason with a bad excuse.
Analyze the Red Herring (distraction).
Interpret the Circular Reasoning fallacy (begging the question).
Connect the Post Hoc fallacy to superstition (it happened after, so it was caused by).
Apply a reverent tone to the reading of God's Word.
Analyze the genre of the passage to determine reading style.
Interpret the emotional context of a Psalm or Lament.
Connect the reading to the listeners' understanding.
Analyze the meter (iambic, etc.) to guide pronunciation.
Interpret the mood of the poem through tone and pacing.
Connect the sound devices (alliteration) to the delivery.
Analyze the logical flow of a famous speech.
Connect the main points to a central thesis statement.
Analyze the physical symptoms of anxiety vs. excitement.
Interpret the audience's body language to gain confidence.
Connect preparation and practice to reduced anxiety.
Analyze the 'less is more' rule for slide text.
Interpret the impact of color and font choice on readability.
Connect the visual aid to the spoken point (don't distract).
Compare two different answers to the same question.
Analyze assumptions behind a statement.
Interpret the Socratic method (teaching by asking).
Connect questions to discovering truth together.
Judge a debate based on reasons, not popularity.
Evaluate the strategic use of time in a debate round.
Evaluate the 'High, Middle, and Low' styles of speech.
Evaluate the ethos, pathos, and logos of the invention.
Evaluate the validity of the opponent's evidence.
Evaluate the risk of sounding artificial with too many schemes.
Evaluate the use of Anthimeria (changing part of speech).
Evaluate the 'Undistributed Middle' term error.
Evaluate the Tu Quoque ('you too') defense.
Evaluate the pacing required for a congregation to follow.
Evaluate the prosody of a recorded performance.
Evaluate the effectiveness of different organizational patterns (chronological vs. topical).
Evaluate the psychology of public speaking anxiety.
Evaluate the rhetorical impact of data visualization.
Evaluate the definition of terms in a discussion.
Construct a case for Lincoln-Douglas (Value) debate.
Synthesize flow-charting (taking notes) to track arguments.
Synthesize formal logic with propositional logic (basic symbols).
Construct a speech that balances all five canons.
Synthesize natural talent with disciplined practice in Delivery.
Construct arguments using the Topoi (places to find arguments).
Synthesize biblical wisdom with rhetorical invention.
Construct a formal case with Contentions and Sub-points.
Synthesize clash points to summarize the debate.
Construct sentences using Tricolon (rule of three).
Synthesize schemes into formal writing and speaking.
Construct complex metaphors to explain abstract theology.
Synthesize tropes to create vivid mental images.
Construct valid syllogisms (Modus Ponens, Modus Tollens).
Construct a critique of a political ad detecting fallacies.
Synthesize the study of fallacies to sharpen critical listening.
Construct a prepared reading for a church service.
Synthesize vocal variety to highlight theological emphasis.
Construct a performance of a complex poem (e.g., Eliot or Donne).
Synthesize facial expression and vocal modulation.
Create a strong opening hook (question, fact, story).
Construct a complex speech using classical arrangement (Dispositio).
Synthesize evidence and narrative into a cohesive argument.
Construct a personal routine for pre-speech preparation.
Synthesize vulnerability and authority in delivery.
Create a poster with clear text and images.
Construct a professional slide deck (e.g., PowerPoint/Keynote).
Synthesize speech and visuals for a seamless presentation.
Construct a line of questioning to expose a contradiction.
Synthesize the dialectic process (Thesis-Antithesis-Synthesis).
